translated: Notes on the thirty-second fascicle of the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra
Spoken by Fuhui, listened to by Suiting
As for properly established, the meaning here is asking about the person who first cultivates the five contemplations such as impurity.
If one who wishes to cultivate the mental state of impurity, etc.,
what kind of skillful means should that good friend use to cause them to abide in the five aspects such as disgust, etc.?
Therefore, the treatise text says properly established, etc. As for hearing, etc.,
although here it is the method of disgust with dharmas based on the gate of the contemplation of impurity,
if one is cultivating the contemplation of kindness, etc., it is also the same as this question. As for house fire,
it refers to sons and daughters, etc. who do not inherit the family business. As for if you now see, etc.,
it means if one sees oneself, one's own relatives and kinsmen, and the village suffering, one should give rise to disgust.
The speaker should know. As for explained in detail as before,
it means that one should give rise to disgust with those who encounter suffering and difficulty in one's own body, one's own relatives and kinsmen, and one's own village.
The same as what was explained above. Cultivation refers to
the present manifestation of illness. The nature of the illness
refers to the seeds and habits of the illness.
Death is also the same as this. For these reasons
refers to the three kinds of characteristics of the bodies, relatives, villages, etc. of others, which then give rise to suffering. By these things
refers to the ability to end suffering by giving rise to disgust with things such as prosperity and decline. In cessation
refers to the ability to cut off the five dharmas such as purity that are to be cut off by the five contemplations. I or forgetfulness
refers to the four phrases below, which clarify the meaning of contemplation based on their specific characteristics. In all the trainings, there are transgressions and forgetfulness
corresponds one by one with the four phrases above. Nature
refers to the mind seeking precepts when receiving precepts. To put it briefly
Here there is a question.
What is the meaning of the two kinds of general and specific contemplations?
Therefore, the treatise answers, In all the precepts, etc.
It means that because the two dharmas of the present precepts and the preparatory practices are complete, two kinds of observation are established. As for Å›Ä«la-pÅ«rvaka,
it means that if one violates the precepts, one will certainly regret it later. As for removing hindrances, etc.,
it means that because of joy, one is able to remove all hindrances. As for such aspects, etc.,
there is a question here.
In the various holy teachings, the terms joy, delight, and pleasing mind
are mentioned. What are the differences between these three terms?
Therefore, the treatise answers, The first is called, etc. As for you should reduce, etc.,
it means that because the mind is refined and moistened,
one is able to eliminate worldly greed and worry,
and attain the two dharmas of worldly and supramundane tranquility and insight. As for if it is like this, etc.,
it means that because of the aspect of detachment, one turns away from all black qualities,
and because of the aspect of delight, one inclines towards all white qualities.
Therefore, the treatise text says, by refining the mind, etc. As for all aspects, etc.,
Namely, the ten characteristics of form and so forth, birth, old age, sickness, male, and female. As for the eight of desire and so forth,
Namely, desire, anger, harm, emptiness, territory, relatives, and immortality.
The objects that were received in the past are the basis. As for the desire and so forth,
Namely, the five dharmas that are to be countered by the five contemplations such as impurity are called secondary afflictions.
They are not the five hindrances. As for therefore such and so forth,
Namely, each of the three dharmas such as characteristics has the five faults such as this suffering is not holy and so forth. As for moreover one should at and so forth,
Namely, due to the three minds such as the one-pointedness of the mind that is the basis,
One is able to give rise to the six aspects.
Each one counteracts the three previous faults.
These six dharmas are all free from the views of self and so forth established by non-Buddhists. As for or the light of a lamp and so forth,
Namely, when the previous faults such as cultivating impurity arise,
One should gradually cultivate the four kinds of samÄdhis such as the fire light, etc. The text says having taken such and such,
it means that although one who cultivates the contemplation of impurity can take the characteristics of light and abide in the contemplation of impurity,
due to the power of repeated practice or when the pure characteristics appear,
one should again discern the twenty kinds such as blue and swollen, etc. The text says first on one object, etc.
It means that among the five contemplations such as impurity, etc.,
one can bind the mind to any one object,
and can turn away from the five kinds of inverted views such as purity, etc. The text says and also within that, etc.
It means that one who can understand among the six characteristics,
the confused and the unconfused naturally appear. The text says and also within that, etc.
It means that if the inverted views such as purity, etc. arise, one should not follow them. The text says many good things,
it means the most handsome men and women, etc. among many people. The text says just these many good things, etc.
This analogy appears in the Ä€gama sÅ«tras and the SÄá¹ƒkhya SÅ«tras.
The World-Honored One firmly transformed in the country of Uá¸á¸iyÄna.
King Jyotiá¹£ka invited the Buddha and set up various musical performances. He then said to the World-Honored One:
Now that I have set up this music, is there anything superior to this music?
The World-Honored One said:
I do not hear it at all.
Who distinguishes good and bad in the music you have made?
The king said:
I personally saw and heard the music performed above.
Why do you not distinguish it?ğŸ”½The World-Honored One used this analogy to illustrate.
The great and so forth arise means the gathering of various people and classes.
Because of this, it can cause means because the correct category is the cause,
the six kinds of benefits such as the continuous greedy mind and so forth arise in the five stages of contemplation.
Correct mindfulness is the category of stopping.ğŸ”½Correct knowledge and practice together
is the category of contemplation.
The meaning shown here is:

For those practicing the five contemplations, in each contemplation, the upper essential is to operate both calming and contemplation together, only then is it called good practice. As for no discrimination, this is the category of calming. As for discrimination,

For those cultivating the five contemplations, in each contemplation, the upper [level] must have both stillness and contemplation operating together in order to be called good cultivation. As for no discrimination, this refers to the category of stillness. Having discrimination refers to the category of contemplation. As for at the time of entering, etc.
The meaning here is explained as follows.
The previously contemplated characteristics of blue-black decay, etc., are gradually increasing in number, and are therefore called provisional.

Now, in this true aspect, one should contemplate all the blue-black decay of oneself and others, which has been unknowable since beginningless time, and is therefore called true. As for also not cultivating, etc.
It means that not just one time cultivating blue-black decay, etc. is called the accomplishment of contemplation.
At all times, without the need for effort, one is able to see the characteristics of impurity, etc. spontaneously, and is therefore called equal to the long time.
This is called the characteristic of the accomplishment of contemplation.
Therefore, the treatise text says equal to that time, etc. As for the various characteristics do not manifest, etc.
It means that in this category, the characteristics of purity, etc. all do not manifest. As for not causing to abandon, etc.
Also, because it does not abandon the contemplation aspect. As for signless,
it means being without the ten signs such as form. As for non-discrimination,
it means being without the eight kinds of thorough investigations. As for tranquil,
it means being without the five secondary afflictions. As for the mind accompanied by the light of lamps,ğŸ”½it refers to the light of lamps. As for the mind accompanied by illumination,
it refers to the light of fire. As for the mind accompanied by bright purity,
it refers to the light of the sun. As for the light without darkness,
it refers to the light of the moon. As for cultivating Å›amatha, etc.,
it is combined with each of the above four texts. As for narrow,
it means contemplating one person, etc., which is called narrow. As for frequently, etc.,
it is combined with each of the above four texts. As for toward one's own beloved, etc.,
it means that within one's own beloved body, one should give rise to the certainty of death and send it to the charnel ground.
Therefore, there are twenty characteristics such as blue-black, etc., that gradually arise. As for repeatedly, etc.,
it means combining with each of the characteristics such as blue-black, etc., above. As for you should further, etc.,
it means that the four formless aggregates are all suffering, impermanent, and non-self, and are therefore called contemplating the three dharmas such as feeling, etc. As for signless,
it means contemplating the ten characteristics such as the formless, etc., of feeling, mind, and dharmas based on the chapter on the bases. As for non-discrimination,
it means being without the eight kinds of mental probing. As for tranquil,
it means being without the five secondary afflictions. As for no function,
it means being without the creation of self. As for no longing,
it means being without the probing of faults. As for no agitation,
it means form, etc., are unshakable. As for free from burning and affliction,
it means being without afflictions. As for bliss of cessation,
it means realizing nirvana. As for practicing with the objective supports, etc.,
Because form and other sense objects do not disturb and agitate. As for the four formless aggregates, etc.,
Because feeling, appearance, mental formations, and consciousness change moment by moment. As for you should cultivate this,
It corresponds one by one with the above ten texts. As for without disturbance,
If based on the Tibetan text, it does not say without disturbance but rather disorder.
The meaning here is as follows.

By observing the loss due to the distraction of the three dharmas of feeling, etc., one is able to cultivate the observation of the impermanence, etc., of the three dharmas of feeling, etc., which is called without distraction. As for you should,
It means that with regard to the three objects of feeling, etc., following conditions and transforming is called the stage of non-fixity. As for past exhaustion and cessation,
Because feeling, etc., are all dharmas that have passed away. As for loss of mindfulness,
If one conditions the three dharmas of feeling, etc., one loses right mindfulness. As for arisen from mental disturbance,
It is because the three dharmas are all produced by a disturbed mind.
The three of characteristics, etc., are explained according to the previous. As for superior,
Because the three of feeling, etc. give rise to the three inversions of pleasure, etc. The phrase you should...
is combined with each of the previous passages. The phrase these dharmas...
means that the three dharmas of feeling, etc. are ultimately all produced by deception and illusion, etc., because of the five characteristics. The phrase you should...
is combined with each of the above five phrases. The phrase you should...
refers to abandoning the objects of pleasure, etc. The phrase filthy bedding
refers to the place where men and women have intercourse. The phrase always
refers to what is done by those still learning. The phrase ultimately what is done
refers to what is done by those beyond learning.
Both of these have two kinds of preparatory practices: uninterrupted and severe. The phrase attaining the inferior...
refers to attaining the fruits of those still learning. The phrase vast and perfect
refers to the stage beyond learning. The phrase blameless pleasureğŸ”½refers to supramundane pleasure. The phrase pleasure of desire
refers to mundane pleasure.
It refers to the pleasure of the desire realm. As for with joy and pleasure,
It refers to the pleasure of the first dhyÄna. As for without joy and pleasure,
It refers to the pleasure from the second dhyÄna upward to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. As for the distinctions within it,
It refers to the distinctions in the characteristics of the four immeasurables such as loving-kindness.
As will be explained one by one below. As for when entering,
It refers to when entering the contemplation of loving-kindness. As for the four establishments of mindfulness and so forth,
It refers to the three such as feeling that can destroy the three kinds of inverted views such as pleasure, called the object of destruction. As for the characteristics of expression,
It refers to the expressive form that is good or evil. As for only the establishment of mindfulness of the body,
It refers to giving rise to the establishment of mindfulness with regard to the three kinds of bodies such as enemies, friends, and so forth. As for the intention of resolve,
It refers to the intention of conceptualizing characteristics. As for furthermore, I toward them and so forth,
If one does not give rise to loving-kindness toward sentient beings who have already passed away in the past,
It cannot eliminate the seeds and habitual tendencies of anger in the store consciousness. As for immeasurable and greatly excessive,

it means that compared to the previously cultivated false characteristics, the cultivation of the mind of loving-kindness and compassion towards all enemies, friends, and so forth in the past is greatly excessive. As for not truly real,
it means that it is not not the meaning of true reality, because it is the meaning of true reality. As for yapo niÅ›Ätaá¹ƒ bhinna, this is a Sanskrit term.
It means the cause is not equal. As for the branches are as explained before,
it refers to the three gates of samÄdhi, the gate of non-dissipation, the gate of contemplation,
and the meaning of these three gates should be explained here.
Because there is no difference in meaning from the contemplation of impurity,
therefore it is not explained here. As for discriminating and grasping characteristics,
it means that a beginner grasps the four inverted views and wanders in birth and death.
Because of grasping the characteristics of non-inversion, one can escape from birth and death. As for the fundamental karma of birth,
it means because it is the cause of giving rise to good, bad, and other karmas. As for if on one's own body, etc.,
It means contemplating suffering, emptiness, impermanence, etc. in one's own body.
The external body, other bodies, etc. below are the same as what is explained here. The phrase the rest is explained as before means
the chapter on the basis, the chapter on non-distraction, and the chapter on contemplation clarify the characteristics of dependent origination.
As explained before in the contemplation of impurity. The phrase like the sunğŸ”½refers to the hottest time of the day. The phrase blazing
refers to the time when the qi is sick. The phrase spreading
refers to the fire that is uninterrupted. The phrase subtle discrimination
means that the previous five elements are easy to understand because they are coarse and obvious.
The characteristics of this consciousness element are subtle, so the practitioner must first make subtle discriminations before understanding its characteristics. The phrase this characteristic, etc.

means that one should understand that within the four great elements body there is only the seed of the consciousness aggregate, the seed abiding in its own nature, and the ability to cognize objects without a self. The phrase throat tube
refers to the throat passage.
and distension. The phrase among the ten kinds, etc.
Namely, the ten kinds of derivative form.
Because it is the supported object.ğŸ”½As for even more so,
It means that the true characteristics surpass those provisional characteristics.
Because they are immeasurable. As for one part,
It means that even in a single finger joint, there are still innumerable subtle dust motes.
How much more so for the entire body, etc.? As for external wind,ğŸ”½It refers to the east and west winds. As for coarse holes coming and going,
It refers to the exhalation and inhalation through the mouth. As for following the wind-aggregates,
It means that the winds coming and going through the pores follow the body's movements. As for included in the wind-aggregates,
The winds in the pores belong to the external wheel. As for hidden in the wind-treasury,
The winds in the pores are difficult to see. As for immeasurable wind-aggregates,
The three kinds of wind-aggregates mentioned above are all gathered in the practitioner's body. The second is the simile.
Therefore, the treatise says it is like defilements, offenses, cotton, etc.
It means that a person who has entered the attainment of cessation has no inhalation and exhalation.
It means that when one cultivates the contemplation of counting the breath, relying on the category of support, the category of contemplation, and the category of non-dissipation,
One contemplates the merits of the category of cessation such as signlessness, and the new and new non-oldness of inhalation and exhalation, etc.
As before, the contemplation of impurity should be explained here.
Because the meaning is the same, it refers to the previous text.
It means that when cultivating the five contemplations such as impurity, etc.,
One diligently practices and combines the cultivation of ardent zeal.
It means that one cultivates uninterruptedly in the country.

It means that one cultivates ultimately in the fruit.ğŸ”½It means that by the power of the causes, namely by the causes of cessation and contemplation, one is able to attract the strong and vigorous lightness and bliss of body and mind.
It means the previous signs.
If one of the five contemplations is to be accomplished,
a sign of lightness and ease like a stone pressing down appears in front of one's head. As for what obstructs the joy of abandoning,
it means that afflictions such as greed can obstruct the joy of cultivating the practice of abandoning in impurity, etc. As for the wind element increasing excessively,
it is because lightness and ease arise from the five contemplations.
The practitioner's body and mind are like the wind.
The practice is upheld without heaviness. As for the appearance of being filled to overflowing,
it means that the lightness and ease born from the path of the five contemplations pervades the entire body.
Because it is like a bag filled to the brim with contents.
It appears as if overflowing.
At such a time, the practitioner's body and mind have a sense of exhilaration, etc. As for adorning the latter,
it means that by the power of lightness and ease,
the body and mind are adorned and relaxed without needing to apply effort. As for gradually retreating and ceasing,
it means that the mind of exhilaration, etc. in the previous stage is of the nature of greed,
and here it is also all eliminated.
Therefore, the treatise says tranquil practice and so on.
It means that after the wind of heaviness and lightness increases and overflows from the peak,ğŸ”½one is then able to enter the cultivation of the five contemplations.
As for the concentration of the form realm,ğŸ”½it means that one can obtain a small part of the four formless concentrations that are free from defilements.
As for obtaining this attention and so on,
there is a question here.

If the beginner has the four attentions such as the increase of the wind of heaviness and lightness in the peak, what are their characteristics?ğŸ”½Therefore, the treatise answers obtaining this attention and so on.
As for having already attained the form realm and so on,ğŸ”½it means that because one obtains a small part of the four formless concentrations that are free from defilements in the form realm,
one has power and ability.
Because one has power and ability in the five contemplations such as impurity,
one is able to purify and eliminate the five objects of purification such as the characteristics of purity.ğŸ”½As for all practitioners,
Namely, the five inversions such as purity, etc. The words although few, arise, etc.
Just as the contemplation of impurity can eliminate the objects that can be considered pure.
The contemplation of loving-kindness, etc. can eliminate the objects that can be increased, etc.
One should know it is also like this. The words not thinking of
Refer to not excessively thinking of objects of desire, etc. The words not enjoying and worrying
Refer to not enjoying clothes, food, etc.
And giving rise to worry. The words all characteristics that accompany
Refer to the characteristics of not enjoying purity, anger, etc. The words not excessively
Correspond with each of the following.
The third fascicle of the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra is completed. The third place of practicing yoga is finished. The words extensively distinguishing the two concentrations
Refer to the two concentrations of signlessness and cessation. The words five supernormal powers
Refer to the fruits of the eight concentrations, such as the first concentration, etc.
Refer to the eight fundamental stages such as the first concentration, etc. The words five supernormal powers
Refer to the concentrations. The words differences in birth
It means that the births in the first dhyÄna and so forth are not the same. As for the various characteristics,
It means being free from the desires of the two realms of form and non-form.
The above seven gates are established based on the worldly path. As for contemplating the truths,
It means the person who practices the stage of preparation. As for penetrating reality as it is,
This is the stage of seeing the truth. As for extensively discriminating in cultivation,
It means this is the stage of cultivation.
